CHENNAI -
THE DETROIT OF INDIA

Chennai is the capital city of the state of Tamil Nadu. It is the sixth populous city of
the country catering to 4.6 million over an area of 1,189 Square Kilometres. The
estimated GDP of the city is around 58.6 billion USD which is further expected to
reach up to 191 billion USD by the year 2025. The city is also considered the fourth
city of India in terms of GDP per capita for ,
the year 2014. The city of Chennai is also the
biggest cultural, economic and educational
centre of South India. The city is also
popularly called “The Detroit of India”
because of the presence of more than one-
third of the country's automobile industry in
the city.

The history of Chennai can be traced back to 400 years. “Madras”, the former name
of Chennai, is believed to have been derived from the name of a village called
“Madraspatnam”. The city was originally located in the province of
Tondaimandalam, an area lying between the Penna River of Nellore and the
Ponnaiyar river of Cuddalore. Madras is believed to be the conglomeration of three
settlements at Mylapore, Triplicane and Santhome. The port of Mylapore,
according to many geographers like Ptolemy, was known to have trade connections
with Romans, Greeks, Arabian and Portuguese traders during the 2” to 16" century
